description.text:
A display rack for showing off flat things, like cards or tinysaur kits. Generated using Python! Will post the source soon. For reasons unknown to me, the tines don't render properly in QCAD (or the preview here), but they show up fine in Corel. Probably a mysterious DXF formatting issue. To generate your own size displays using the python script:
edit the various dimensions in the script (its set for mm), then run it. It will save two files, displayside.dxf and displaysign.dxf

You'll need two sides and one sign.
Cut out of your favorite material, assemble!

author: Myrmecoman

title: TX03 Mount for Eachine Micro Skyhunter

description.text:
This is a remixed TX03 Camera mount designed for the Eachine Micro Skyhunter.

Not yet tested; but designed to screw into pre-drilled 20mm separated holes on the canopy section. Holes on the mount are designed to take M2 (2mm) self-tapping screws to affix to the FPV canopy, and will accept screws with heads up to 6mm (which should include flanged heads too).

Also added a flat front and gradient edge to the camera base to allow for support-less printing. Rounded the back edges off for aesthetics and weight reduction.

Retained the zip-tie gap under the camera (enlarged as I only have slightly too big ties for the original hole size), as I plan to loosely ziptie the camera to the mount as a backup. Will screw (and hot glue to be safe) the mount itself into place on the plane (note: these cameras often get too hot for using hotglue to secure it in place).

I printed at 3 wall, 1.2mm top+bottom, 100% infill, and it's looking good. Very light and strong in PLA.

Chinese Ebay i3 Clone

author: tronluca

title: Drela AG16 Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (35.20g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
This propeller has been designed after the Drela AG16 airfoil coordinates. All tests were done with the Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig All results can be checked below.

The part was printed with slow speed, using a 0.2 extruder nozzle at 0.04mm layer height. Cleaned using an X-ACTO Knife

After this, I went on and sanded it using a 400 grit sandpaper.

Here are the readings for some voltage presets (also visible in the pictures taken):

  • 1.5V => 12.53 grams
  • 2V => 22.05 grams
  • 2.5V => 28.44 grams
  • 3V => 35.2 grams

The files you'll download contain all pictures relevant to the test, with 6 text files that have all the airfoil coordinates used in the build, the printable STL files and finally the SLDPRT files. If you'd like to use this propeller, make sure you have a bunch of 8520 coreless motors.

Use the SLDPRT files, in case you wish to make your own changes to the drone propeller.

P.S. The airfoil plotted with the matplotlib library for python.

author: Myrmecoman

title: Decathlon vioo clip 500 light adapter for Ikea Sladda bike

description.text:
The Ikea Sladda bicycle comes with handy mounts for their lights. However, the lights themselves require plenty of AA batteries, and are of a lesser quality.

Searching for replacements, I found these Vioo Clip 500 lights from decathlon. These great little lights are good for city use: they are designed more for the cyclist to be seen, rather than to see, charged via usb, and interchangeable for front and rear use.

The adapter can be mounted on the rear rack using the original bolt provided by Ikea. It can also be mounted on the front reflector using the extension provided, and an elongated M5 bolt (3.5mm long) and nut.

Two holders and the extension take about an hour to print at a 0.4mm resolution.

author: Narsica

description.text:
English :

In order to maintain the glass door closed, i created a little door latch. This part is made for a glass door witch thin of 5 mm. I used synthetic glass.

For the rotation of the latch, you have to screw a screw of 4 x 10. The hole is present.
Adjust screwing to obtain the right friction during rotation of the latch.

The static part is screwed with 2 screws of 4 x 15.

Maybe simple but really efficient !

Français :

Afin de maintenir la porte vitrée fermée, j'ai créé un petit verrou de porte. Cette pièce est conçue pour une porte en verre de 5 mm. J'ai utilisé du verre synthétique.

Pour la rotation du loquet, il faut visser une vis de 4 x 10. Le trou est présent.
Réglez le vissage pour obtenir le bon frottement pendant la rotation du loquet.

La partie statique est vissée avec 2 vis de 4 x 15.

Peut-être simple... mais vraiment efficace!

author: RiKoMetal

description.text: This is my first 3D scan, I have sold my printer so unable to test (waiting for a new one), it was scanned with the Nextengine, I think it is tight, the model is small about 4cm so I have left as solid, any feedback and tips welcome.

comments.text: To be clear, a scan would be between 8 and 24 passes (3 minutes a pass) and this would take 30 minutes + at high resolution, the finished scan would then be loaded into another application for finishing (merging images, cleaning meshes making watertight, sculpting and a few other steps) this takes anything from 45 minutes to 6+ hours depending on how good you want the finished scan. The software that comes with the scanner does the job but not very well. Regarding the scanner I purchased mine from a company that is a specialist is scanning, they had 4 of them but sold them due to speed, I am unaware of anywhere in the UK than rents scanners, to buy new would be about £6500 in the UK (broken down £2850 +vat, maintenance contract (about $295 +$295 if I remember correctly (scanner & upgrades)), enhanced software $995(needed for high res) , turntable $995, I dont have a cost for the additional software but seem to remember about £1000, purchasing a used one and sharing a licence cost about £3000, hope this helpes.
comments.author: micropete

comments.text: Oh okay - so the actually turntable scan took 30 minutes = 8-24 passes * 3 minutes per pass.
comments.author: micropete

comments.text: Sorry to be nosy but I am curious - what do you mean "no longer have the scanner"?  Did you rent the scanner?  I wonder if there is a place I can rent a scanner like Nextengine (or maybe LMI HDI 109 would do even better?) to capture tiny details like on the HeroQuest figures...
comments.author: pemsw

comments.text: Thanks for the comments but no I longer have the scanner, I ran out of time, each scan would take about 4 hours, I hope one day to get another and maybe will do some more figures.
comments.author: micropete

comments.text: Awesome scan!  Any chance you'll scan more of the HeroQuest pieces with your Nextengine scanner?  I'd especially be excited to see scans of the four heroes and additional monsters.  thank you
comments.author: pemsw

comments.text: HeroQuest! :D
comments.author: meyo

comments.text: I knew I had seen it somewhere. Was racking my brain...I remember painting one many years ago.
comments.author: meyo

comments.text: This printed very nicely (see my make) directly in Cura, thank you so much for this, it brought back memories from some 20 years ago! I went through old stuff in the attic, and found my game box, but unfortunately pretty much all the figures are either broken or missing :( I would love to fix the game up by printing the missing figures, any chance you'd enjoy making more scans of the game models? In case copyright is a concern, perhaps send them privately, I can show proof that I own the original game etc., although it looks like the game is not being manufactured anymore.
comments.author: juj

comments.text: A side from saying "decimate that thing's polygon count" this really shows the difference between a high end scanner and the stuff folks are making with the digitizer.
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: I agree - Nextengine picks up more tiny details than EinScan-S despite both being advertised as 0.1 mm.  EinScan-S is pretty good overall at ~$1200 but Nextengine at ~$3000 must be better based on this scan.

title: SPEkTRUM DX9 mount for Immersion RC's EzUHF LRS TX

description.text:
Simple mount for Immersion RC's EzUHF Long Range Transmitter for SPEkTRUM DX9.
The goals were:
1) Get the EZUHF antenna in a different orientation than the DX9 2.4 GHz antennas.
2) Minimize any interference from the EzUHF 70cm into the DX9.
3) Provide as much cooling as possible.
4) Allow access to the back of the DX9
5) Keep all switches & knobs easily accessible.
6) Mount the EzUHF 70cm antenna as vertically as possible when in use.
7) Light weight ( ~30g currently)
8) Still be able to use SPEkTRUM's vertical carrying case without removing the EzUHF.
9) Minimize the amount of metal around the DX9 antennas. Mounts with 2 ZIP ties or 3 zip ties.
a) All instructions printed on EzUHF TX are visible.
b) Easy to remove if need be.
Front Mount print time: ~42 mins
Rear Mount print time: ~90 mins
Added a slightly more stable V2 version of the Rear mount part.
Please keep in mind, here in the USA, you need an Amateur Technician license to operate with an EzUHF LRS TX. Most local Amateur Radio Clubs run monthly testing session, and it's a rather simple, inexpensive test & and you will learn a lot that will help you with the radio & electronics in general. When connecting ezUHF TX to the DX9, make sure you enable SLAVE mode in the Trainer section of the menu. To use the ezUHF TX,
1) Select the model on the DX9
2) Enable SLAVE on the DX9
3) Turn off (yes off) the DX9
4) Plug in the cable from the ezUHF to the DX9 trainer port. (DX9 will power up with the DX9 power switch in the OFF position)
5) Apply power to the ezUHF. I am currently using ezUHF firmware 1.5.0 with IRC_Tools 1.40, for the DX9 Airware 1.06 I've tested both Hi/Lo power on the DX9, and I have not noticed any drop out... however, as a HAM, I also know the local 70cm freqs and avoid those and stay away from the 70cm repeater towers.

5 Shells
.2 mm Layer
20% Infill
For REAR use support for best results.
Insert your Immersion RC TX before mounting.
I've included the X3G files if you use MakerBot Replicator2.

comments.text: Shame this wont directly work with the DX18... exactly what I am looking for...

description.text:
This is a modification of Flyingbear-P902 -Auto Bed Leveling.

Non-printable parts

define NUM_SERVOS 3

title: Spindle Lock for Precision Matthews PM25-MV Milling Machine

description.text:
Owners of the Precision Matthews PM25-MV Milling Machine quickly discover how difficult it is to change tools in the absence of a spindle lock for the R8 spindle. This simple 3d printed part solves that need by making it easy to temporarily hold the spindle from rotating while changing the tool. No modifications are needed to the machine, it's lightweight and plenty strong for the job.

Here is a youtube video of the lock in use:

description.text:
This is advanced Data logger.

https://youtu.be/X3RiIEgv-_Y?list=PLW1IBsHOodG-cKctVMPX8WWRV_M8ycJtd

Includes: GPS, BME280, MPU6050 & microSD card module.
Write data as: lat,lng,alt,dir,speed,sat,date,time,temp,pres,elev,ax,ay,az,gx,gy,gz

With help of the http://www.gpsvisualizer.com/ you can draw many parameters from this
unit.

Tested and worked very well. I have powered this unit with my powerbank 5000 mAh for 12 hours. And the power bank capacity drop to 92%. Have minimal power consumption depend only from writing frequency in Arduino sketch. All files and schematic are included.

I bought modules from here(look at free shipping and the lowest price):
https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?minPrice=&maxPrice=&isBigSale=n&isFreeShip=y&isNew=n&isFavorite=n&isMobileExclusive=n&isLocalReturn=n&shipFromCountry=&shipCompanies=&SearchText=arduino+mini+pro+328&CatId=0&g=y&initiative_id=SB_20170528124950&needQuery=y&tc=af

https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?minPrice=&maxPrice=&isBigSale=n&isFreeShip=y&isNew=n&isFavorite=n&isMobileExclusive=n&isLocalReturn=n&shipFromCountry=&shipCompanies=&SearchText=bme280&CatId=0&g=y&initiative_id=SB_20170528125035&needQuery=y&tc=af

https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?ltype=wholesale&d=y&origin=y&isViewCP=y&catId=0&initiative_id=SB_20170528125035&SearchText=mpu6050&blanktest=0&tc=af

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/GPS-module-micro-USB-NEO-6M-UBLOX-satellite-positioning-51-single-chip-for-Arduino-STM32-routines/32752381973.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.94SUrI

https://www.aliexpress.com/wholesale?minPrice=&maxPrice=&isBigSale=n&isFreeShip=y&isNew=n&isFavorite=n&isMobileExclusive=n&isLocalReturn=n&shipFromCountry=&shipCompanies=&SearchText=Double+Side+5x7+cm+Prototype+Universal&CatId=0&g=y&initiative_id=SB_20170528125605&needQuery=y&tc=af

Printer:

Stanlez 1.0

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

300 microns

Infill:

15% honeycomb

Notes:

Time for printing whole thing on my printer is 45 minutes. For other printer is approximately from 1 h to 1h 20 min.

After print, use foam to fix inside a position device/reduce vibration. Little piece fo plexiglass for top hole for blue LED. And fixing case part together with velcro strap. All modules are soldered to one piece of PCB all holes board and stick together with white double-side tape, two or 3 layers(because we dont want any unwanted contact). Then I add gray wires and fix all connectors with hot glue. It is take a time and precision to solder modules right and properly. PCB board i used is 5x7 cm but I cut the edge to the minimal size of modules.
I designed it on the developed GPS unit, USB cable and microSD card slot. In program Blender(https://www.blender.org/)

title: Mean Well PSU Mount for 2020 Aluminum Extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was originally designed for a Mean Well SE-600-24, but I've included the Fusion 360 (F3D) and STEP files if you'd like to modify them to fit your particular PSU. I used it to mount the PSU to 2 pieces of 2020 aluminum extrusion on the bottom of my printer.

There are 3 STL files: 1 for each of the mounts, and 1 plate that has both on it together. The reason for the 2 different mounts was originally I planned on having holes on the bottom to line up with the PSU's bottom screw holes, but they weren't needed, so I abandoned them.

The mounts in the images were printed in Hatchbox Blue PLA.

For assembly, you'll need (8) M3x6mm screws to attach the mounts to the PSU and (4) M5x8mm screws with (4) T-slot nuts to attach the mount to the extrusion.

Watch it print here: https://youtu.be/NyOsPuzZXZM

Printer:

Eustathios

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed this at 0.28mm to save time since this is a functional part that doesn't need to be pretty. The worse resolution you print it, the worse the holes will be, but if your printer is well-calibrated, there should be enough tolerance to get the proper screws through them even at 0.30mm. If not, you can always clean them out with a drill.

This was printed on a Eustathios Spider V2 designed by the talented +Eric Lien.

description.text: I made some additions/changes to Wired1's excellent Openbeam 1.4 printer design to suit my needs. Namely changes to the extruder to utilize a Printrbot Extruder. I also adapted some of Hossmachine's OB1.4 derivative.  Namely the X axis endstop/Z axis adjustment screw combination and the Z axis endstop bracket.  I broke the y-carriage into two pieces to print on the Jr.  All of the changes were made to the original stl files using Tinkercad.

All of the parts were printed on my Printrbot Jr version 1 in PLA.  Including the y-carriage.  I broke Wired1's y-carriage into two pieces.  Printed both on the Jr, then glued them together with super glue.  After I got my OB1.4 calibrated pretty good, I printed a new carriage on the new printer.

description.text:
Hello, here you can find my spool adapter and spring nut for 6mm threaded rod. These components allow you very quick spool change and very quick attaching different width of spools.
The spool adapter allows to use spools with internal diameter between 30mm and 60mm. The adapter is designed for two bearings 626 2Z.
The spring nut is designed for very quick secure spool adapters on 6mm threaded rod. Simply press the button, go throught the rod to spool adapter, then release the button and tighten the nut. The tightening moment depends on used spring. Spring nut is designed for 6mm spring. I used the spring 15x6x0,6mm. For secure the button in the spring nut body you will need screw M3x16mm.
In attachment you can find two models of the button. Both are the same, the different is only in hole for M6 half nut.

author: beerdart

print_settings.Notes:: Shown parts is printed in PETG.

title: Anet A6/A8 Bed Level Thumbwheel Upgrade

description.text:
Manual bed leveling the Anet A6/A8 is a little awkward and could be made a lot easier. There are some good solutions on the net - I took the best, made modifications and kept it simple.

This solution allows you to cover the entire hotbed with a build plate as you no longer need access to adjusting bolts from the build surface. All adjustment is done with the thumbwheels!

All metal! at the hot end - this allows you to heat up the bed for ABS, Nylon and other high temperature filaments without melting your bed level adjustment.

>> If you like it, please click the like button :)

From the kit you will need:

  • 4x Springs
  • 4x Screw M3*30

Additional you will need:

  • 8x M3 Nut (Optional: Use self-locking nuts for thumbwheels)
  • 4x Steel/nylon M3 washer (Optional: I used large, but regular is OK)
  • 4x Spring Cap (Print model)
  • 4x Thumbwheel (Print model)
  • A 3mm or 1/8" drill for stripping M3 thread

Note: To make this bed level upgrade, you need to strip the M3 thread in the Y carriage aluminum frame. This can not be reversed.

If your heatbed has copper traces under the washers, I recommend using nylon washers instead of metal to protect the heating element (eBay Search).

Just follow the photos to assemble.The M3 nuts is a tight fit in the thumbwheels to prevent them falling out.

2018 January 13.: Added thumbwheel for Nylock nuts.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

2 perimeters, 3 top and 2 bottom layers.

Tip: Print all parts at once, this will help the small parts cool between layers and give a better result.

Shown parts is printed in PETG.

• Anet A6 Power Supply Cover, Upgrade
  • Anet A6/A8 Bed Level Thumbwheel Upgrade
  • Anet A6 Extruder Heatsink Fan Spacer/Support Upgrade
  • Anet A6/A8 Threaded Frame Mount Clamp, Upgrade
  • Anet A6 Auto Bed Level Probe and Fan Mount Upgrade
  • Anet A6 X Belt Holder/Clips, Upgrade
  • Anet A6 Y Belt Holder Upgrade

comments.text: I'm basically using a similar mod. Just without the washer and without the spring cup. So if you don't want to print them: they're not a must. It'll just work with the stock parts + thumbnut + regular nut to fix the screw onto the hotbed.
comments.author: DruckiMCDruck

comments.text:
I printed these out over the weekend and the following tip might help if you use PLA.
After printing, I used a pair of long nosed radio pliers to squeeze the nut partially into the thumbwheel. However, this had the effect of warping the thumbwheels somewhat. What I did was to put some boiling water in to a jug and then drop the thumbwheels in the water for a couple of minutes. PLA goes pliable in hot water, so after a couple of minutes I quickly removed each disk (the radio pliers are handy here!) and swiftly squeezed them in a vice to flatten them out and cool them down. You have to be really quick here, as the PLA starts to harden again within 10 seconds or so of removing from the water. Once removed, you'll have a flat thumbwheel and the nut nicely squeezed into the centre.
comments.author: M0ZGB

comments.text:
Would it work by printing 8 of the spring cups and using 4 of those instead of the washers to go against the hotbed?
I hope to be printing these out today - looks like a great workable mod.

comments.text: The PLA won’t hold up against hotbed. That said, the washers aren’t critical.
comments.author: M0ZGB

comments.text: The reason for the washer is to protect the heat bed from the end of the spring and fastening nut. If there is no electrical traces where the spring/nut has contact with the heat bed, it can be left out.

comments.text:
Thanks. I only use PLA at present, so wondered whether the cups would be fine against the hotbed temperature wise.
To be on the safe side though, I'll source some Nylon washers. Thanks for the design though!

comments.author: CanterburyFlyer

comments.author: CanterburyFlyer

comments.text: Wonderful! Really easy to print and install. Thank you!
comments.author: Puntoste

comments.text:
This is really game-changer. Leveling is so much easier.
One warning: washers (in original configuration, springs) rest on heating pcb, protected only by solder mask. This could result in it cutting thin mask and short across heating element, potentially killing power supply or control board. I just used some cardboard between washer and bed, should be ok for PLA. Few layers of kapton would be better.
comments.author: bashfullsson

comments.text: Good idea the Kapton tape. I have that right there ready to go. Missing all my small drill bits though arrrrrgh :-)
comments.author: bashfullsson

comments.text:
Thank you.
On all the PCB heatbeds I have seen, there is no active copper traces in the corners, only the solder mask. Compared to the original setup, the washer is protecting the heating layer from the sharp edges on the end of the spring.
In my opinion there is no danger of a short and the modification is safer than the original construction - if you want more isolation I would suggest using a nylon washer under the metal washer. Nylon will resist the heat when printing ABS (100C).
comments.author: bashfullsson

comments.text: It is indeed safer. On my bed traces were definitely under springs, something worth checking for. I'll probably just use thick teflon tape, i'm almost sure i had some .2mm somewhere.
comments.author: Area51

comments.text: I would recommend nylon washers. They are cheap and easy to get on eBay: https://www.ebay.com/sch/i.html?_nkw=m3+nylon+washer
comments.author: bashfullsson

comments.text: This was one of the best things I have done.  There was a guy on Anets I was watching on youtube  that drilled his bed screw out and raved about how much better it was. I actually had an issue where my thread got crossed on the bed screw and had no choice but to drill it out, best mod ever, never looked back. This one is a winner
comments.author: thingae

comments.text: Nice idea!
comments.author: CAD_NINJA

comments.text: Awesome. I was just thinking about doing this myself  and then though, "Someone must have this on Thingiverse already...
comments.author: sxty8goats

comments.text: Do you need to do anything to the top of the bolt to stop it freely turning as you try to adjust it?
comments.author: grimvoodoo

comments.text: The bolt is fixed with the M3 nut under the hotbed (covered by the spring), this prevent bolt from turning when using the adjusting wheel. See photos.
comments.author: grimvoodoo

comments.text:
Hi, nice upgrade ! I wish i had a drill right now :p
Other thing, what is the caramel colored tape/surface on the bed ? It looks like the adhesive around the cables on the extruder.
Is is working well ? I'm currently using the classic adhesive paper tape but i still have to heat up to 260 for the first ABS layer :/
comments.author: Darknoodles

comments.text:
Thank you.
The tape on the hotbed is Kapton tape - good for ABS print. I plan to replace it with a PEI sheet.
With ABS slurry it works well for ABS printing, but PEI can be used "as is" and works with a lot of other filament types.
comments.author: Darknoodles

comments.text: my 4th print ever and it is fantastic.  It only took trying to level the bed twice for me to search for a better way.  This is it.
comments.author: Vonzep

comments.text: This works great! It is very nice to not have to use a screwdriver to level the bed. Thanks!
comments.author: kharwood92

comments.text: Great mod, i'm doing this now. One suggestion, you can use M3 spring/lock washers instead of the nylon locking nuts to help lock the thumb screw from moving inadvertently. The M3 lock nuts are typically bigger height wise and may have problems sticking in your thumb wheel since they are a little thin. Overall great design, thanks!!
comments.author: joeynational

comments.text: damn i dont hjaver a drill
comments.author: zjxlsti

comments.text: Aluminium is soft - You'll find a way :-)
comments.author: zjxlsti

comments.text: great design. used it for a week and leveling is much easier now. thanx
comments.author: qrisonline

comments.text: Thank you for the feedback :-)
comments.author: qrisonline

comments.text:
Do you use the stock springs of the printer? And why M4 bolts, are M3 not enough?
Thanks for the feedback.
comments.author: ridsel

comments.text: I use the printer kit springs and bolts (M3), not new M4.
comments.author: ridsel

comments.text: So the stock springs and M3-30 screws from the A8 work with this?
comments.author: CrashcupMN

comments.text: Only tried with Anet A6, but I expect the A8 to be the same. Photos shows stock kit springs and M3 screws.
comments.author: CrashcupMN

comments.text: the fit for the nuts was so tight I couldnt get 2 of them in, but heating the opening up with a lighter made it soft and I could push the nut right in.
comments.author: Hannemaster

comments.text: I just heated the nut with a lighter and pushed it into place. Great tip.
comments.author: Hannemaster

comments.text:
Thank you.
Depending on filament type and slicer used, the fit could be too tight.
Using heat to fit the nut is a great solution, as you did. Making the model 2-5% larger before print is another solution.
comments.author: Hannemaster

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: aluay

comments.text: In this design the M3 screw is locked to the heat bed with a nut. For the bed leveling to work, the screw must be able to move freely through the threaded hole in the y carriage. Therefore the threading must be stripped with the drill (3mm or 1/8").
comments.author: aluay

comments.text: Drill the carriage, not the hot plate, right?
comments.author: Area51

comments.text: Yes, using 3mm drill to strip M3 thread in y-carriage. The hole should just be big enough for the bolt to move freely up/down, not side to side.
comments.author: A1Topgun

comments.text: You can even improve that with self-locking M3 nuts. Other than that - great idea.
comments.author: desrtfx

comments.text:
Thank you.
The pressure from the spring combined with the friction between y-carriage and thumbwheel should prevent the bed from "self adjusting".
But as you point out, the regular M3 nuts in the thumbwheel can be replaced with self locking M3 nuts (with nylon).
comments.author: desrtfx

author: Area51

title: hair trimmer guard comb / Sabot tondeuse

description.text:
Sabot de tondeuse pour la très (trop) fragile W Tech Titanium de Babyliss.
Ce guide correspond au guide intermédiaire 3-18 mm qui dans mon cas devient plutôt un 4-18mm.
Il est beaucoup plus robuste que le modèle original.
...................................................................................

Hair trimmer cutting guide for the very (too) fragile W Tech Titanium from Babyliss.
This guide corresponds to the intermediate guide 3-18 mm which in my case becomes rather a 4-18mm.
It is much more robust than the original model.

15-06-2017 : Added a bigger one. (V5). Print it reversed with support.
18-10-2017 : Added a stronger version of V4 (V6).

Printer:

Hypercube

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Imprimé en ABS.
Un support d'impression est déjà inclu (en jaune sur les images) dans le but de maintenir l'adhérence des fines dents du sabot. Pensez à les retirer avant l'utilisation.

Printed in ABS.
A small support is already included in order to make the fine tooth stuck to the print bed. Remember to remove the support prior to use it.

comments.text:
Excellent !!!! I need to print this ! By the way I bringed my hair trimmer back to life after the battery was dead.
I soldered two AA or AAA (can't remember) instead of the old ones and it is now back on track !
Babyliss Guard combs are really brittle pieces of shit. Amazing some guys like you did the 3d model.
I think that appart of the battery and the comb guard, this trimmer design is dead simple and can last forever. THANK YOU !
comments.author: chaosbc

comments.text:
Your welcome ;)
As my V4 was recently broken, I have designed a slightly stronger version of V4 (Tondeuse Babyliss V6.stl).
comments.author: chaosbc

comments.text: Thanks!! Better than the original one!!

These are brackets for the FT-5 2020 aluminum stock.
I made these to replace the Melamine parts and add an extrusion to help key in the rails for better alignment.
Please feel free to criticize (hopefully constructive!) or suggest improvements and changes.

Corner A and Corner B are made to fit depending on how one rail meets another rail. You will notice that the one extruded key in the corner is in a different location on each.

When getting ready to print you may need to "mirror" the parts for a kind of "left and right" part.

Graveyard by AMR [created on 3DTin]

This is a simple slide mount project box to attach to any 5mm thick panel that can hold up to a 40mm x 70+mm pcb (voltage regulator in my case) and two round rocker switches. I tapped into the 24v dc power supply of my Replicator and installed a DC to DC converter in order to supply LEDs and cooling fan, both independently switched.
10% infill, I used supports. Slide onto 5mm lip of your printer.

comments.text:
Great model with awesome detail.
I tried printing it at 1:144 scale (about 120mm length) laying on its belly with lots of support. But the horizontal and vertical stablelizers got paper thin at this size. Got nearly impossible to remove the support without damaging anything.
Maybe I'll try printig it again at another size. The sliced up remix by Time268 looks promising.

comments.author: BaelRathLian

comments.text: Loved the model, thanks for the first "non-cartoonish" upload of this BA fighter on thingiverse. I cut it up into chunks with Netfabb and scaled them to one half of the original model size for printing. This may not seem big, but the default model is huge... even at half size the final product is nearly three feet long. All the parts print on my Ultimaker, (200mm x 200mm x 200mm) and I will probably upload them as a derivative once I finish printing them. Thanks again!

print_settings.Notes:: As the mechanical effort of sustaining the bed is now done by two opposite axes, the parts does not need to be strong. So a 25% infill is enought.

description.text:
Add a second z axis on your Microcube (on the front) to improve bed stability.

This modification is compatible with the original Microcube: you can reuse your existing bed plate, as you juse need to replace the two original bed lever by those provided, and print again some original parts.

You will need:

  • Printed parts:
    • 2 x dual_axes_bed_lever.stl provided in this thing (replaces the original bed lever)
    • 1 x new Z_axis_platform_mount from the original Microcube parts
    • 1 x new z_axis_motor_mount_rod from the original Microcube parts
    • 1 x new z_axis_bearing_mount_rod from the original Microcube parts
    • 2 x new z_motorshaft_shaft_coupler from the original Microcube parts
  • Metal parts:
    • 2 x LM8UU linear bearings
    • 2 x 8mm smooth rod 200mm
    • 1 x M5 threaded rod 160mm + M5 nut
    • 1 x motor for the new z axis
    • nuts and bolts
  • An alternative LCD mount if you use a LCD screen, as the original one is incompatible with a new z axis on the front side.

Instructions:

  • Print the plastic parts
  • Remove your bed plate and the bed lever (you can't put the lever away, you don't need the). Keep the screw on your bed as is, it's a drop in replacement
  • If you use an LCD, remove it, and put the original mounting parts away.
  • Mount the new z axis on the front side of the printer, as explained in the original Microcube build guide (of course there is no need for Z endstop screw on the new z bed platform).
  • Fix your bed on the two z plateform using the new bed levers.
  • If you use and LCD, fix it using the alternate mount

Tips:

To reduce friction and ajust the z axis, loosen all the screw of the Microcube structure.
Then, manually turn one of the axis to have each platform (not the bed) at exactly the same height (use a rule or a caliper to measure the distance between the platform top and its z_axis_bearing_mount_rod top).
Once they are at the same side, use the motors to make the bed full up and full down a few times.
While moving, ensure the structure is loosen: the rod will move a bit, having the 2 z axis falling in place to be perfectly parallel for each other. Help the structure by and if necessary.
At the end, gently tighen all the screws.

Beware:

If you are using 28BYJ-48 motors, you may need a new A4988 motor stepper driver. On RAMPS, z axis have 2 connectors, for two motors like in our case. But the power repartition between two connected motors is passive: it needs the motors to have the same winding resistance, so that they will received the exact amount of current.
Unfortunately, based on my experience, 28BYJ-48 are not accuratly made, and their winding resistance are really different from one motor to another. So, if 2 motors are connected to one driver, the one with the lower resistance will receive more current than the other: at best the higher resistance motor will loose step, at worst it will not turn at all and the other motor will fry receiving all the current.

Measure the resistance of each coil of your motors: if it is too different, you will need to connect the second z axis motor to a dedicated motor driver (use the second extruder motor of the RAMPS), and configure your firmware to replicate z motor move to E1 motor driver.

Printer:

RenRen 3D Pro (Kossel XL)

As the mechanical effort of sustaining the bed is now done by two opposite axes, the parts does not need to be strong. So a 25% infill is enought.

description.text:
Communicator from The Order 1866. I really loved this game's aesthetic and wanted to have the shoulder radio as a prop.

This prop is designed to be assembled and used as a functional prop-piece, so some parts reflect this design choice. The Handle is hollow for a battery compartment, and the main body is mostly empty so that a PCB and electronics can be glued in. Also, the top button frame is thicker than the game model so that a button can be put inside of it without it snapping off every time it's pushed.

Also the file titled "The Order Communicator" is a fully assembled .stl with all the parts in the proper arrangement that can be printed as a single piece instead of as individual components.

Let me know what you think!

Notes:

Make sure to set scale to x1000. When I export from .ipt to .stl it shrinks the files for some reason. Let me know if you run into any printer-specific problems and I'll add them here.
This allows your to vertically store spools from a serger sewing machine. Print multiples of the part and after placing the spools stack another of the printed parts on top, repeat ad-infinitum.

title: Anet A8 (Prusa) Z axis synchronising gizmo

description.text:
Z axis sync solution for Anet A8 printers

Problem: the two z axis screws can easily become miss-aligned. Any pressure on one side will create an offset, requiring the other side to be adjusted every time you print.

Solution: Sync the two screws with a pulley and belt system.

You will need two bearings (688ZZ, 16x8x5mm), couple of M3 nuts and screws, and ~800mm of 6mm GT2 drive belt, same as used on the x and y axis.

Glue the pulley halves together, push the nuts into the slots.

Push the bearings into the holders.

You'll need to remove the top frame plates, one at a time, slide the pulley over the screw, then the bearing cap (might be a tight fit), and re[lace the top frame plates.

Loop the belt around the pulleys, pull tight and mark where the ends overlap.

Use the tool provided to cut the belt ends at an angle, make it a couple of teeth shorter than you measured, then put both ends in the tool and glue the ends together with superglue (helps if you smear the joining tool with Vaseline or butter, to stop sticking to the tool).

Take the top plates off again, one at a time and place the belt around the screws, replace the top plates .Fit the belt over the two pulleys, hopefully will be the right length. Leave the set screw loose on one side.

Finally, set the height of the x axis to the same height at both ends, tighten the set screw on the other pulley.

Now when one z screw turns, the other turns too. Set your bed height, that's it. Happy printing!

Frame Brace

To stop the two uprights being pulled together and bending the top frame piece, I designed this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2646309

You can find all my Anet A8 upgrades here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/FredGenius/collections/anet-a8-upgrades

comments.text: Did you keep the two motors?
comments.author: misterxfiles

comments.text:
Yes, seemed like the minimum solution to the biggest problem. MKSA has another solution, see comments below.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830451
comments.author: misterxfiles

comments.text:
Just came across this.I can see plenty of issues. You keep the two motors, you don't seem to provide belt tension, the belt splicing is fragile, you don't solve the wobbling, just the out of synch. etc....
OK, a small step in the right direction but still plenty more needed.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Hi, thanks for taking the time to comment.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Here is what I did on my Prusa Geetech (Al frame). https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1830451
Still valid although I moved a few steps forwards as I mainly experiment solution for a new machine.
As for splicing, I give also links to what some guys here did. Personally, I use a more complex method inspired by what is used in the industry but the links given are good enough.
The real issue with the Anet is the flimsy frame.
Some guy posted here what he did on his Anet similar to my set up (one motor, two lead screws...) but he had to reinforce its frame with threaded rods, braces etc..
Wobbling is mainly due to bad couplers, bent screws (M8 is not suitable as leadscrew)
comments.author: FredGenius

comments.text: I thought about something like that, but the lead screws aren't long enough, they don't reach the top of the frame. I have fitted a front frame brace, and a cross brace at the top. As you say, the acrylic frames are flimsy.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: The leadscrews are long enough if they are secured at the top and free at the bottom. By doing so, they work in tension, self align and are not overconstrained.
comments.author: FredGenius

comments.text: You are right, I've had another look at your design and I like. More contact area between drive gear and belt would be good - perhaps an idler gear which could act as a tensioner too.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: You need 6 tooth. Can be done with a bigger pulley, tension is done by moving the motor as I did or if not possible indeed use and idler.

title: Quiet Retraction Feeder Dual Bowder Extruder for Ultimaker 1

description.text: This is a work in progress. This is a second quiet retraction extruder mount for the Ultimaker 1. It is inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53690. The idea is absorb the motor vibrations so that the Ultimaker case does not act as a rosonance body. It is planned to have the second extruder a little higher, so there is space for the filament rolls and also that the filament clamp is accessible. The second version (quiet retraction high) of the mount is reinforced, in case you want to mount more than just the stepper and the usual stuff. Also it leaves more space between the filament roll and the extruder. Both versions are thought for 608z bearings. To build an extruder you need either 2x the quiet_retraction_second_estruder.stl and the middlepiece or 2x quiet_retraction_high.stl and the middlepiece. For the bowden clamp use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17027. For the large motor gear use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25501. The smaller gear is provided along with the extruder stl. The vibration absorbtion is really phenomenal! Retraction noise is reduced to a minimum. Happy to hear your comments!

It could be assembled without printer disassembling. Just move head along of Z-axis for a few inches.

The end-switch should be mounted with roll to inner side of printer.

The screw should be fixed tightly in the base part after you assembled it.

title: RPi Overclocker Case Lid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: After some research and experience with Retropie, I realize that to enable correct performance when playing games on Nintendo 64, overclocking the RPi 3 is necessary. To properly overclock the RPi 3, there are hardware requirements such as 2.5A 5V power supply adapter and increased cooling. My solution to enable increased cooling is the RPi Overclocker Case Lid. It is a lid which incorporates (2) 30mm 5V brushless fans to pull heat from the system.

title: NEMA 11 motor mount for Microcube Z Axis

description.text:
I had a lot of issues with 28BJY-48 motors for Z axis used on the original microcube (unreliable, often get stuck, pretty sensitive to any hard points in threaded rods, slow, ...), that were amplified when adding a Second Z axis (need a perfect synchronisation between z motors, which seems hard to acheive with 28BJY as thier is always a hudge difference between coil resistance of 2 different motors), and a Hotbed (a bit more weight to support).

And 28BJY was a no way to try adding a z probe for autoleveling on Microcube: autoleveling need many up and down move of z axis to measures enought point on the bed plate. 28BJY always get stuck after a few point (really few, 2 or 3), and they are too slow too measure at least 9 points for a good mesh leveling correction.

After searching for alternative motors, I choose to try NEMA 11 motors. I select them because:

  • Their size is 28mm, which fit perfectly in the original z_axis_motor_mount of the Microcube, so it's easy to adapt some mount for them.
  • They have a lot more torque than 28BJY (I estimate about x8 for the ones I'm using).
  • As NEMA motors are a standard with high quality manufacturing constraint, I expect them to all have the resistance, inductance and current consumption, like their big brothers 14, 17 and 23).
  • I never used NEMA 11 motors before, this only reason is a go.

I bought 2 (http://www.ebay.fr/itm/311777193131) and mount them. The perfectly meet my expectation. These little guys are incredible: 8x more power and torque, accurate, never get stuck. I was able to multiply Z speed and acceleration by x10 without any problems.
Since I'm using them, I never had any issue with z axis on my Microcube. I can have a lot of full Z up and down in a raw, in only a few minutes.

You'll need:

  • 1 x z_nema11_adapter (provided in the thing)
  • 4 x M2.5x5 or M2.5x4 screws
  • 2 x M4x16 (or longer) screws
  • M5 threaded rod about 145mm long (depends on your motor ; you can shorten the existing one ; see below in instructions)

Note: using these motor will reduce the Z max of your Microcube by about 20mm. Which means you will only have 70/75mm of height print volume for the original structure size.

Instructions:

To use NEMA11 in your Microcube it's easy:

  • Buy one ot two of them (depending if you have a second z axis or not)
  • Print z_nema11_adapter (provided in this thing) for each motor.
  • Remove the actual 28BYJ
  • Remove the M5 threaded rod, you need to shorten or replace it. It depends of the shaft length of your NEMA11 motor (I used 145mm length M5 threaded rod for mines).
  • Put the new M5 threaded rod
  • Screw the adapter to the motor with M2.5x5 or M2.5x4 screws
  • Put the motor in place and fix it to the original mount with M4x16 screws

These motors can take a lot more current than 28BYJ, so you need to ajust your motor stepper driver using VRef! The motor I used are rated to 0.8A.
If you have a 2 z axis Microcube, you can connect the two motor on the same z driver (the motor coil resistance are perfectly matched, and their higher current consumption made them less sensitive to current variations).

Firmware:
You have to ajust you firmware settings for Z axis:

  • z step per mm: 4015 (for 1.8°/step motors, like the ones I used)
  • z max feedrate : 2 mm/s
  • z home feedrate : 2 mm/s
  • z max acceleration : 5 mm/s²
  • z max jerk : 0.2 mm/s

Printer:

RenRen 3D Pro (Kossel XL)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Easy to print. Simple part with not much mechanical effort.

Add an heated bed to your microcube, to improve bed tickness for PLA, and allow it to print PETG, and more (maybe ABS if your heater patch is powerfull enough to reach 110°C).

Beware: An heating bed require a lot a power. You MUST ensure your power supply is strong enough. The printer alone need at least 60W (says 70W for safety). You power supply must be 70W PLUS the Watt power of the heating patch you will be using (plus another safety margin, to be sure). I'm using a 120W power supply for a 40W heating patch.
It's even more important if you are using a cheap chinese power supply (which are usually goods, but often lacks of security cutoff for that price).

I'll need:

  • An aluminium plate, 150x150mm, 1.5-2mm tickness (less, and it may bend, resulting with an unplane bed ; more tick will work but impact the heating speed). Cost me about 4€
  • A 12V heating film that fit your aluminum plate.
    • I'm using this one (100mm, circle, 40W), but search "polyimide heater" on ebay & his friends.
    • Silicon heater patch are also good choices (but a bit more expansive).
    • The Watt value of the patch has a direct impact on the heating speed and and maximum temperature. The higher, the better, but you MUST ensure your power supply can drive it. And too high power are useless for that printer size (I think above 50/60W is useless ; below 20/25W will be hard to use).
  • A standard 100k NTC thermistor
  • Kapton/polyimide adhesive for fixing thermistor and insulation material
  • Optional: a 150x150mm glass or mirror for a better adhesion and plane.
  • Optional: insulation material and/or cork sheet

**Instuctions:"

  • Drill 4 M3/4 holes at the corner of your aluminium plate, the center at 5mm for each side (like you should have done for your actual bed plate)
  • If you intend to use a glass/mirror, countersink the holes on the top of the plate to use contersunk screws
  • Fix the heating patch on the bottom of the aluminuim plate, on the center. Ensure sur wire are on the same side of the RAMPS of the microcube
  • Put the thermistor on the center of the patch, and fix it with a large piece of Kapton. The wire on the same direction as the heated patch wires.
  • Fix the wires to the plate with Kapton
  • If you use insulating matertial, cut them at the aluminium plate size, and fix them using Kapton. Cotton/heat resistante material first, cork last.
  • Add screw and spring on each corner, fix your bed on the Microcube plateform
  • Connect the patch wire to the RAMPS heated bed output (D8, the one near the main power in).
  • Connect the thermistor wire into the appropriate ntc sensor (the one juste next to the hotend thermistor).
  • Configure your firmware to enable heated bed. This bed can easly support a 120°C max temperature (if your patch can reach this temperature).

Insulation:

It's not necessary, but it will improve the heating speed and the max temperature.

For information, this is what I measure with my setup (2mm tickness aluminium plate, 40W 100mm diameter polyimide heating patch) :

Without insulation:

  • ambiant (25°C) to 60°C in 4 minutes
  • max temperature: 80°C

With insulation (2mm insulating cotton + 2mm cork):

  • ambiant (25°C) to 60°C in 3 minutes
  • max temperature: 95°C

comments.text:
I'm using a fishing line (a breaded one, don't use a mono filament nylon string, it will slip on the pulley), and it's working fine.
I had an issue on the first time with the line slipping around the pulley, causing some drift. I finally found that was because my line was too tight: if the line is too tight and have too more tense, the pulley does not drag the line.
Maybe your kite string is too tight.

comments.text:
too tight; possibly. It is very tight, hard to imagine it slipping but thought it might be.
I was wondering if there was something I could add to the stepper pulley to make it tackier and grab the string more.
Then, I figured maybe just make new pulleys that have teeth and use a belt like all other printers.. But then I asked you and you say no problems. So maybe it just me.
:)

description.text:
I have not printed this one yet. I am waiting on more wood PLA and a hardened nozzle. This is similar to the hexagon planter I designed previously, but with squares. I moved the corner lugs/feet from the planter to the tray on this one so that there would be considerably less support needed.

The tray sits nicely underneath it with the raised corners acting like locking lugs to hold the tray cleanly underneath the planter if it is pushed or slid around.

If I were to print it, it would be with a Prusa i3 MkII at 0.20mm with supports only for the planter because of the corner overhangs. I like to use 20% cubic infill, but you can use whatever you want. Just remember, there is a bit of a span and the wet soil weighs more than you think, so don't get too thin on the infill and perimeters.

I would print it at 4 layers top and bottom, and 2 perimeters minimum.

The model can obviously be edited to provide jumper pin sockets for needed pins

description.text:
This handle can be quickly and easly clip on the frame of the Microcube, to transport it.

It require some sewing material and competences.

**You'll need:"

  • 2 x soft_handle_support.stl
  • 2 x r_soft_handle_support.stl (reversed one)
  • 2 x 8mm tube 70mm long (you may have scraps of the Microcube structure)
  • A 40mm width 40cm long strong tissu for the handle itself. And beld or an old bad strap for example. I use a piece of judo belt (3€ in any sport shop). It must be tick and strong.
  • Super glue
  • Sewing needle, good strong thread

Instructions:

  • Print the parts
  • Make a handle terminal using a soft_handle_support and a r_soft_handle_support, inserting them in each side of a 8mm tube. Glue them on the tube to be sure it'll never move. Ensure the hooks of each printed part are aligned, and distant by 70mm. The best thing is to clip the item on the Microcube structure, on the rear top tube (in its final position), and wait a few hours for the glue to get strong.
  • Make the second handle terminal.
  • Fix a end of the belt to a terminal:
    • Make a hem at the end of the tissue belt if needed.
    • Place that end around the rod of a terminal, having the belt covering itself on 30-40mm
      on its bottom. Take care of the side (look at the picture).
    • Sew it tight and strong.
    • Then sew it again to be sure (we don't want our precious Microcube to fall on the floor and broke).
  • Fix the other belt end to the other teminal, after checking and adjusting the length to your need. Take care of the side of the terminal, the hooks of the teminals must clip from the outside to the inside, to better mechanical resistance.

I sew the end belt on the bottom of it once clip on the printer, for aesthetic.
If you are not confident enough with your sewing skils, sew it on the top, it will be a bit more resistant. Or better: ask someone that can do strong seam :)

Et voilà! Now you can clip and un-clip the handle in a few seconds to carry you Microcube.

Printer:

RenRen 3D Pro (Kossel XL)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

60%

Notes:

These parts needs to be really strong, has they will support to whole weight of the printer (in fact, a quarter of the whole weight for each part).

They were created to be strong, but a high infill an ticker shell is recommended.

author: latisen

title: Plastibot Expanded X-axis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Plastibot Printers I look after are starting to show their age. Most of them have had their original hotends replaced with J-heads, but those too are wearing away. As such, I've decided to start switching out the depreciated J-heads and Makergear V1s for shiny new E3D V6 hotends.

Because of their Incorporated fan, the new hotends are slightly too large. That's where these files com in.

All Plastibot files can be found on the Github page.

These new parts are 10mm wider toward the back of the printer, allowing room for the fan to fit.

These parts were modified using Autodesk's Tinkercad

  • X Carriage.
  • X Idler.
  • X Motor.
  • X Carriage Bearing Holder.

author: benjtoa

description.text:
Hinge to make the door easily removable on the Bibo2

I liked the hinge by Macbolan75 but the measurements were a little off for the Bibo2 so I made the needed changes.

Changed the location of the holes making them closer together which barely closes the gap at the top and changed the thickness of the top hinge to better fit the Bibo2's door (also decreased it by 0.1mm since taking the pictures so it should fit even better now).

This also eliminates the need for the spacers on the Bibo2's door hinge.

What I'd really like to do is make every single part of the bibo a bundle of snap together components so it can be taken apart and snapped back together quickly and easily.

comments.text: I agree about the door being in the way a lot. Snap components sounds interesting. I'll have to give that some thought. PETG has great snapping properties, strength and heat resistance and that's what I like printing with. I'll have to see if I can make a snap-on version of the laser mount and maybe the extruder setup to make those snap swap-able components.
comments.author: Macbolan75

comments.text: You're welcome. I put both a lock washer and a flat washer between the stepper motors and the hot end bar to get the feeders filament out hole to line up with the hot ends. Next time I have it apart I will measure how thick a washer needs to be to get it right on. Also the top of the mounting holes at the top of the feeders needed to be wallowed out a little for the feeders to mount on the stepper motors flush.

author: Tadly

print_settings.Notes:: May need some filing to ajust the parts and make them clip into each other fluently.

description.text:
Note: This is a work in progress only for the firmware part: I had some problem having repetier firmware using this probe on z-max connector, and does not had enough time yet to look a it. But it's ok, for the mechanical part (printing part, assembling and testing).

This is a manual z-probe holder. "Manual" mean you have to clip the probe yourself before lauching an auto z leveling, and then remove it before printing.

This probe is not made to be used at the begining of each print to make a z home. It's for lauching a plate probe leveling for time to time, by mesearing 9 to 15 point on the bed. As a bed plate is never 100% plane, each point may have a slightly z difference, the firmware will compute from them a mesh representation of the bed (with this hollows and bumps), and use it during the print to compensate by moving slightly the z axis (using the z motors).

There is to parts:

  • z-probe_fixer.stl is fix for good on the x carriage, using the same screw used for the X endstop. You just have to use a bit longer M2.5 screw
  • z-probe_holder.stl is the moving part. It can be cliped on the probe_fixer before launching the auto mesh probe procedure, and removed after. A microswitch (the same as use for x/y/z endstops) have to be screwed on this part, and connected to the RAMPS (the z max endstop).

From my first tests, the offset of the probe from the nozzle are:

  • x: -10
  • y: 10
  • z: 2.9

RenRen 3D Pro (Kossel XL)

author: kevinete

description.text:
Now you can have your DNA (or any other microcentrifuge sample) and wear it, too!

For the first DIY Bio meet we did the classic DNA extraction lab, where you extract your DNA from cheek cells and store it in Eppendorf tubes to take home. A popular twist on this experiment is to run string through the tube, creating a necklace.
Of course, just running yarn through the Eppendorf cap hinge is pretty janky, so I created this as an alternative! You can snap your sample into the necklace and wear it proudly.

The string slot was designed to take dog tag chain or lanyard clips, so it should also take any other jewelry chain or cord just fine.

This is designed for 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes. If anyone is interested in other diameters let me know and I'll revise the code so it's parametric!

To snap the tube in, point either the hinge or the opener tip so that it's perpendicular to the flat back of the necklace and push.

title: Space-filling molecular models: Sulfur and Phosphorous expansion pack

description.text:
This expansion set lets you make sulfur and phosphorous containing compounds, which along with the other expansion sets will give you will give you just about everything you need to make most biological molecules.

Sulfur sits just below oxygen in the periodic table, and like oxygen will generally singly bond with two other atoms at an angle. That angle is generally about 96 degrees, but it can be many others. This is the sulfur you will need for most biological compounds (Sulfur96); The example I've shown is ethanethiol, which is the chemical they put in natural gas so you can tell if it's leaking. Sulfur can also have up to two oxygens double bonded to it. The most common example of this is sulfate (Sulfur2), which I've shown as sulfuric acid. Sulfur can also have just two double bonded oxygens, that forms sulfur dioxide (Sulfur120). In this molecule the oxygens form a 120 degree angle; many other sites will gleefully explain why this happens so I will not bother. You can also have just one extra oxygen bonded. The only example of this I can think of is dimethylsulfoxide, or DMSO. "OK, what is DMSO," I hear you ask. DMSO is an extremely useful solvent which can be used to dissolve most medications, in fact it works so well that many researchers use it when another solvent (like water) might be better (if I sound like a pharmacologist with some issues with DMSO you would be correct). DMSO readily penetrates the skin including anything dissolved in it (such as a drug). While this sounds like a useful way to avoid injections, DMSO tends to give you profoundly bad breath so it's not used much. By the way, since this is the only molecule of it's type I can think of, I set the sulfur up so it would make DMSO exactly (SulfurDMa, the oxygen goes in the socket isolated from the other two). So if you really want to make DMSO, you know how to do it.

Sulfur also forms some aromatic compounds, generally having five membered rings (the example I show is thiophene). I'm afraid I cheated a little here; sulfur is actually so large that it distorts that other atoms of the ring (not uniformly either); because I didn't want want to remake all the other atoms, I just distorted the sulfur (SulfurPh5b). This gives you an idea of how much space sulfur takes up, which is really the purpose of space-filling models anyway. If someone's thesis depends on this being right, we can talk. As another example of sulfur compounds I have included sulfathiazole, which has two sulfurs in different chemical environments. Sulfathiazole is an antibacterial agent which isn't used much any more, but which has a surprising number of references in popular literature (check Wikipedia). Sulfur is actually capable of many more valence states than I've shown here, so believe it or not you're getting off easy.

Phosphorous is almost exactly the same size as sulfur, the bond lengths are just a little shorter though. I probably could have just printed sulfur in a different color and called it phosphorous, but I stand by quality. Speaking of color, while the color of phosphorous is not as standardized as it is for other atoms, it is usually not shocking pink (this just happened to be the color I had available). Phosphorous is also capable of a large number of valence states, but for the most part for biological chemicals it's pretty much restricted to phosphate (as represented by phosphoric acid above). One remarkable thing about phosphates is that they can join together, as in pyrophosphate or adenosine triphosphate (ATP) which is the major energy carrying molecule of as far as we know every cell.

OK, a word about oxygen. While it makes up half of the earth's crust, I haven't deemed it appropriate to give it it's own expansion pack. This is mainly because most oxygens look pretty much the same; they can bond two other atoms at an angle. For most alcohols and ethers, that angle is about 107 degrees. For water it's 104 (I haven't included it because you can only use it to make water). For this expansion pack though, I needed some more oxygens. One of them (Oxygen3S) I just took the fillet off one edge so it looked better bonded with sulfur (it printed better too). I tried to use it to make pyrophosphate, though, and found out that the phosphates just wouldn't go together. So I looked it up and found that the dihedral angle for oxygen binding two phosphates is between 126 and 129 degrees (OxygenPP2). When I made that, they went together perfectly. I had a similar problem when I tried to attach the triphosphate group to the ribose of ATP. Again, when I looked it up. it turned out that that angle is 117 degrees (Oxygen117). The fun thing about 3D printing is that when you need a different oxygen, you can just make it (I've heard that some people have a different definition of "fun;" I really don't understand this).

This is probably more than anyone wanted to know about sulfur and phosphorous, but if you decide you want to print more molecules, check out the starter set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1720048), the carbon expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730299), the aromatic expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1754393), halogen expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730099), and nitrogen expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1753583)

description.text:
This is a handle and screw cap to attach my turbine fidget spinner (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2305864) to create a pinwheel.

I have included a low profile screw (for more permanent attachment) and a larger, easier to grip screw if you decide that you want to interchange spinners on the handle often.

To print the screw cap properly, it should be printed on it's own, without anything else on the build plate. I found that because it's so small, the threads print cleaner if the extruder nozzle does not have to move part to part.

author: brianwebster

description.text:
You just composed a world hit, but you cant play it because the drummer probably has his holidays. Don't try to find him and 3D print a replacement instead. Two drum sticks are operated by two wheels with a number of teeth, up to your choice. By printing alternative wheels, you can program the beat. Two wheels are added as an STL file. An OpenSCAD file is included, so you can easily print your own wheels. By changing the voltage over the miniature geared DC motor, the frequency is changed.
https://youtu.be/ecxUzuLXm4E

Centripro for gopro hero, v4 in my case. This thingy was designed by me cause I could not find such centripro as I want it using with the protective housing swapped to the left side and easy mounting. The middle wall has the hole in case there is no time to get the camera out and the screen is needed. Made a hole for the shutter button, but it is actually not needed. Made two holes in each of the wings for the fishing line, as well as 2 holes at the bottom to bind the gopro to the main line so that the safety cord does not get into the lens. Printed with 20% infill and it was strong enough. You need gopro's bolt and nut. But in my case it holds very nice without nut.

Added handgrip STL, firstly the idea was to make spinning one, but to simplify came with this design. Anyway I recommend to use something like a ring instead.

Added video example, first glitching part is 60 fps and smooth part is 120 fps.

Enjoy!

This is my Rasptop (Raspberry Desktop) that I designed. This runs on a 12v input. There is an LM2596 voltage step-down for the Raspberry PI 3. It is very portable and can use the 7" monitor or just connect to any display. I set it up so it can run on an 11.1v RC battery. I can also plug in my solar controller that I made and run it off of my 30-watt solar panel as seen in the above link. The HDMI I used was a little tight, I have a 90-degree angle one but I couldn't find it. All in all, works pretty well.

title: Intex pool cover, snap on bracket

description.text:
well I just bought an Intex pool with there cover. And the damn cover just dont stay when it's windy, so I put 3minutes in cad and did this snap on bracket to secure the cover better and easier! Put atleast 6 of these depending on your pool size you may need even more and Print them in petg/abs or something that can withstand the outdoor! (PLA aint the best one for this)

This also helps alot with putting on the cover by your self. Just snap one side on first then pull it over the rest and snap them on also! This will help to hold one side fixed for you to pull the rest!

Ps. The only difference on the 2 STL files are the resolution, I always export highres, but 77mb may be big for some people so I made a lowres one to!

This is made for ~45mm diameter pipes...

Tell me if yours got another measurement and I will ad that one to!

EDIT 170530: V2 version update, now with both sides angled up so inside won't chafe the cover with it's edge.

title: Kopplingar för 16mm VP-rör / Fittings for 16mm PVC pipes (inner diameter 13.4mm)

description.text:
BILDEN VISAR EN TIDIGARE VERSION. DEN ÄR NU UPPGRADERAD FÖR ATT INTE VARA SÅ VASS I HÖRNEN.

Kopplingar för VP-rör, 16mm. Själva kopplingen har en diameter på 13.4mm. Om det skulle vara någon skillnad, så är dessa för rör från Byggmax. 3m rör kostar idag ca 10kr.
Skriv ut med en bra kalibrerad skrivare, så behöver man inte skruva fast rören med en skruv, även om det är möjligt att göra.

Det finns två clips med. Välj beroende på tjocklek av materialet du tänkte spänna fast.
Får du problem med att clipsen går igenom dukar mm, så prova att skala upp dom, så att de blir bredare.

På sikt kommer det att komma fler delar i serien. Tanken är att kunna printa delar, köpa billiga rör och lite plast. Av detta bygger man sedan ett växthus, 6-8m² för bara några hundralappar.

På gång:
45°-delar för att kunna bygga en pyramid eller ett tak med den lutningen.
22.5°-delar för att kunna bygga en pyramid eller ett tak med den lutningen.
Gångjärn
skjutdörrar (glidlister, ev. med kullager)
Lås
Handtag
Markspjut
Dome-delar

description.text:
This is a variant of a traditional pole rocker for use in the mezzotint printmaking technique. The front plate has points for attaching a rocker blade. Rather than pivot from a fixed point, a back plate mimics the arc of the blade. The fully assembled rocker is designed to stay parallel to the horizontal plane. The entire assembly is designed to be compact, and easily assembled or disassembled for transport.

Front plate is universal, choose from the 4" or 6" back plate according to your blade.
Screw holes are sized for weight sets using 1/4" or M6 bolts
Routed to accommodate a 25mm or 1" wooden rod & PVC pipe.

I have one of this wonderful ringbom stirling motor models. They are fascinating, with the temperature of the hand palm they run already. But you nee to take them in the hand or put them on ice to make them go.
I have nine on the desk just because it's great to see. But some time I'd like to make them run while I do something on the computer. This brought me to the idea to take a peltier element which can be heated electrically.
So I made this striling stand which has an integrated peltier element, a switch and a jack to connect an USB power supply. The peltier I have draws 6A @ 15V. This 70W would destroy my beautiful model for sure. But with the 5V from the USB adapter there flows 1A max and going to be lower when it's getting warm. With this 5W the stirling runs perfectly.

Yes, yes - I know to drive a stirling with electricity is somehow odd, but ......

07/16: Added a new top with a slot for a zip-tie to be used as protection for the clover-leaf transmitter antenna. I smashed one pretty good doing a flip and not pulling out intime before I hit the ground top first.

100mm (=102mm) quadcopter X-frame designed in Fusion 360 as part of my continuing self education in tinkering.

Uses 8.5mm coreless motors with standard 55mm props, a Naze32_brushed F3 (clone) flight controller, an AIO camera and VTX, and a mini Flysky PPM receiver. All in all it runs a little heavier than i wanted (56g with battery) printed in PLA. When I get more ABS I might print it to see if I can shave off gram or two.

Proving to be durable in PLA. Crashed several times this morning (on grass, dirt and concrete) only a few scratches and dings.

Parts List:

Eachine Naze32_brushed flight controller
https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-32bit-ACRO-NAZE32_BRUSH-Brushed-Flight-Control-Board-Base-on-Naze32-for-DIY-Micro-FPV-Frame-p-1076529.html?p=X709229380619201703O

8.5mmx20 coreless motor
https://www.banggood.com/4X-Chaoli-CL-820-8_5x20mm-Coreless-Motor-for-90mm-150mm-DIY-Micro-FPV-RC-Quadcopter-Frame-p-1069067.html?p=X709229380619201703O

Camera and VTX
https://www.banggood.com/Eachine-TX01-Super-Mini-AIO-5_8G-40CH-25MW-VTX-600TVL-14-Cmos-FPV-Transmitter-p-1088374.html?p=X709229380619201703O

Receiver (i already own a Flysky transmitter)
https://www.banggood.com/IRangX-Tiny-2_4G-6CH-Flysk-Receiver-Compatible-with-Flysky-PPM-Output-for-Eachine-QX80-QX90-QX95-p-1089802.html?p=X709229380619201703O

You can also buy an all-in-one flight controller and receiver for your choice of transmitter
https://www.banggood.com/search/brushed-flight-controller-reciever.html?p=X709229380619201703O

Bits and bobs
Nylon spacer/standoffs
6mm, 10mm and nut (could possibly use an 8mm instead of 10 if you get an flight controller with receiver.)
https://www.banggood.com/300pcs-M3-Nylon-Black-Hex-Scre-p-984310.html?p=X709229380619201703O

Rubber Grommets 8mm hole
https://www.banggood.com/20pcs-Rubber-Wiring-Grommets-Ring-Cable-Protector-5678mm-Inner-Dia-p-1070122.html?p=X709229380619201703O

Video of first flight and crashes
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aYObSauye60

Notes:

I used 90% infill on base frame and 20% on top plate with PLA (all I had at moment)
It is very sturdy, has taken a few good crashes on the first few flight. I actually wired it up wrong the first time around (but motors in the right locations (CW, CCW) but then rotated the quadcopter before I soldered the motors to the board. I guess that's what happens when your tired and its 1am. Couldn't figure out why it just spun in a circle on the floor before popping up in the air and slamming into the wall. When i woke up the next morning and looked at the quad i realized my mistake, now it flies great.

title: PLA Cooling Duct for the Hot end Mount for ABS by DtEW
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I really liked the design of "MPSM Side-Port V6 Hot-End Mount for ABS
by DtEW, published Mar 16, 2017" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2180550 This cooling shroud is very well thought out. The airflow is absolutely ideal for printing ABS on the MP Select Minit,

However, I didn't always want to print ABS. I needed to have part cooling when I was printing PLA, So, I made this replacement E3D bracket and Air Duct inspired by "MP Select Mini 40mm part cooling duct for E3D zero-offset mount by wallyTHEgecko, published Mar 27, 2017" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2206583

I really liked the way wallyTHEgecko designed his mount. The cooling duct can be flipped up out of the way when not needed, but it was 90 degrees to the right, and the mount and nozzle opening were offset from center, so I redesigned the mount and the duct in Fusion 360.

The E3D Cooler should be made in a plastic that can handle high temp. I printed mine in PLA because I am still trying to get a handle on ABS printing. However, with the E3D cooling fan powered on 100% of the time, I am confident it can keep the parts cool enough that the PLA doesn't deform. So far, after about 40 hours of printing, everything is still the right shape.

And, now i can control the Cooling Fan separately from the E3D Cooling fan using embedded G-Code commands.

73
VA3TNE

description.text: An original design for a Free Running Logo designed by a 7th grader from The Island School, PS/188.
Gives the Arduino Uno a 0.5 inch stand off mount.  Pockets are for through hole components clearance.  Screws can thread right into the print.

Print with no support.  Break off small support piece at the corner with the notch.  Attach with 4mm or #4 screws from both ends.  
The later versions of the Uno have 2 extra pins close to pin13, I had to turn down the screw head so that it would fit.  I did this by threading the screw into an aluminum stand-off like in the picture, with a lock nut holding it in place so that the screw isn't threaded in completely.  Chuck the stand-off into a drill and hold a file to the side of the screw head while running the drill until it is a small enough diameter to fit the Uno just right.

description.text:
Replacement for the top plate of the $9 Liantian 130 frame. This is probably a clone of something and available under a bunch of names.

Designed to hold the Runcam Swift Micro, the pictures are of an early test version with a generic micro cam.

Designed to be printed out of a rigid plastic, sacrificing durability for lightness, ease of printing, installation and size. Print a couple, though with the low weight and inertia of these setups I'd be surprised if they get broken that often.

Have flown this quite a few times now, big improvement over the previous setup with this frame.

Micro Swift fits perfectly as long as you push it in completely square with the mount points. Provides enough contact area so that you don't have to tighten the screws too much to have a nice secure camera angle.

Still just hot glueing the ligths on the back, can't decide whether its worth modeling some kind of mount for it.

Printer:

MP Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.175

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

Prints without supports, the top of the cutouts need a bit of cleanup, if you want it to look nice. I put a bit of extra material in the edges so that it has sufficient strength even though it might look a little messy.

Same for the fillet in front of the rear antenna mount, adds a bit of strength to the weakest part.

The Space Launch System (SLS) is an American Space Shuttle-derived heavy expendable launch vehicle. It is part of NASA's deep space exploration plans including a manned mission to Mars. The SLS is to be the most powerful rocket ever built with a total thrust greater than that of the Saturn V.

-Wikipedia

This is a 1/100 model of the SLS Block I crew configuration where each section can be printed in appropriate color to produce a final model that requires no painting. In addition each stage can be separated out for play or display.

Printing recomendations

NOTE: This model was printed with ABS on a Zortrax M200 printer and thus other material/printer combinations may not have correct tolerances.

Colors used in this model are:
-White
-Black
-Orange
-Gray

Some parts require sanding and/or glue to build

Notes:

Resoultion and infill percentage were chosen for aesthetic purposes - you are welcome and free to alter as you wish. The same applies to rafts and supports - they are not strictly necessary, and I don't like to use them because it dirties the end product.

Bearings

This file only contains the fidget spinner body. You will need to purchase or print the bearings for this print in order to make it spin. I have designed it such that the holes are a light press-fit size for a 1.125" outer diameter ball bearing.

This file was designed in Solidworks using an extruded boss. The sketch consisted of three circles built around a construction triangle, and three 3-point arcs built around a larger construction triangle. I finished the extrusion with a nice .125" fillet on the top and bottom, then added concentric extruded cut circles onto the body.

description.text: My earlier post of the Heart of Tafiti is kept in a locket in the movie. This is my version of that locket. I printed it in grey PLA using a "Print-in-Place" layout to connect the hinge. There is no clasp but rather the inside of the locket has a pocket to cradle the heart. The weight of the lid and the heart should keep the locket closed for the most part.

Once printed, the bottom layer should be filed/sanded to remove traces of the brim as well as any fusing between the sides that might occur on the first layer. Then gently pry the two sides apart at the bottom (i.e. - away from the hinge). Once this lets go, gently open the lid by applying increasing amounts of pressure until the hinge becomes free.

title: Transistor Tester Base - Hackerboxes #18
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is not my first Transistor Tester, so this is not my first attempt to make a case for it.
When I put my hands on this kit from Hackerboxes #18 (http://www.instructables.com/id/HackerBoxes-0018-Circuit-Circus/), quite compact but packed with different tools like frequency and voltage meters, etc, I wanted to take a different approach from traditional/bulky cases and make a light, minimalistic base to accomodate the pcb and the 9v battery, still allowing access to external power adapter when necessary (replacing the 9v battery).

This is how I accomplished it, using a printrbot simple metal 3d Printer with black PLA (but you can have it your own way with different material and color).

I don't really like metal-plastic friction, so I use four M3 x 5mm x 5.3mm Brass Inset nuts (
Amazon: https://tinyurl.com/yavo62ou) with four M3-0.5 Metric 6mm Length Screws (Amazon: https://tinyurl.com/ya6s3gjd) for a perfect fit.
Usually the insets fit tight in the base without any glue, but you can use hot glue to make sure they don't slip out.

I used a small velcro through the slots on the battery compartment sides, to keep the battery well attached to the base; also, I fixed the battery connector to the base with a nylon zip tie. Check the pictures I've attached to see where and how all parts fit together.

If you want to take a different approach on the insets or anything, you are welcome to edit the project to your needs.
