Each module is designed to hold two rocker blades and each blade can be individually adjusted. Horizontal members can be used to attach additional modules. Modules are offset to produce an inter-locking pattern. The simplest configuration of two modules is shown.

Each module requires two blade carriages and adjustment housings.

Additional items you will need to assemble each module:

(x1) 25mm pillow block bearing, tapped base
(x2) 8mm pillow block bearing
(x4) M6 x 140mm bolt, standard pitch
(x4) M6 wing nut, standard pitch
(x4) M6 nut, standard pitch
(x4) compression spring, O= .343”, L= .75”, W= .034”
(x12) M6 washer
(x4) M6 lock washer
(x2) M10 x 60mm bolt
(x2) M8 x 60mm bolt, standard pitch (or one threaded 8mm rod)
(x2) M8 nut, standard pitch
(x2) M8 lock washer
(x2) M8 washer
(x1) U clamp, 25mm (1”)
(x12) Wood Screws, approximately 20mm (.75”)

Dimensional Lumber required:
24mm x 89mm (.9375” x 3.5”)
19mm x 50mm (.75” x 2”)
25mm/1” rod -cut to 100mm (4”)

title: Jeep Wrangler hard top quick-release knob

description.text:
I wanted to install quick-release knobs on my Jeep TJ to simplify taking the hardtop off. There's lots of cheap bolt kits on eBay and Amazon, but I didn't care for the fact that the heads are all small. I wanted nice large knob heads to make it easy, and kits with large knobs were too expensive.

So I whipped these up in an afternoon. The design receives an M8x35 bolt. I purchased them from Lowe's in packs of two for $1.30 (see pic). After printing, just press a bolt into the hole. The head fit is tight, so you may have to use some tools (i.e. tap lightly with a hammer).

print_settings.Notes:: Supports needed only on the X carriage parts for the motor mounts and where the belt tensioner is located. Do not support the belt mounts as the support is hard to get out there.

description.text:
UPDATE, PLEASE SEE BELOW
Also have a look at this thread in the BigBox forums for more information

This is my IDEX (InDependant Extruder Axes) setup for the E3D BigBox.
It has been influenced by the designs of Chase Wichert and "Björn" from the E3D Forums.
Chase made the initial Dual Titan design and Björn extended it to an IDEX setup.

I just wanted a more compact design in general and a little more open around the hotends for easier installation and cabling.
I made a fixed design without extruder cartridges.
Also I wanted the Z sensor as close as to the hotend as possible.
For the moment there is only the design for the BLTouch sensor.

This design also features 300x200mm build space for both hotends.

Another side effect of the horizontal placement of the motors is that it is possible to use larger NEMA14 motors up to 61mm body length. For example the 14HS20-1504S has a body length of 52mm and a torque of 40Ncm which is as high as the original NEMA17 motor for the X axis.

For the drag chains I used an IGUS Series 4 chain with 25 elements plus the end pieces. You need two of them so 50 elements and end pieces:

  • 2 x chain part number: 04.10.015.0
  • 2 x end pieces part number: 040.10.12

As the end pieces cannot move as far as needed to mount them to the carriages you will have to use a cutter, saw and file to make it possible they can be mounted 90° compared to the chain.
You do not need exactly that chain but at least a chain with a radius of at max 15mm. The supplied chain drag anchors are for the IGUS Series 4 chains.

If you want to mount the fan duct on the right carriage you have to move your camera a little, new mounts provided.

UPDATE:
I added X carriage parts and a mount for the IR probe. Also different fan ducts are needed for the IR probe. Though you can use the BLTouch duct on the right carriage if you want to.
Small changes to some other parts, can't remember which ones.

UPDATE 2:
I change the belt clearance in the X carriages by 2mm, changed parts are all X carriage party (not the clamps!) and the fan ducts for BLTouch.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm layer, 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

20%

Notes:

All parts are oriented as they should be printed!

Supports needed only on the X carriage parts for the motor mounts and where the belt tensioner is located. Do not support the belt mounts as the support is hard to get out there.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
this is a humidifier i made in tinkercad.
it uses an ultrasonic atomizing module to atomize water into a mist

you need a 40mm fan, and the misting module.
optional is hot glue or super glue\ epoxy.
print all pieces.
The tall cylindrical item is the base.
slide the misting module into the inner smaller ring
Take the wire and you will see 2 round holes, stick the wire through.
The rubber plug on the misting module should fit snug.
If too small,use the optionals to fix it, if too big use sand paper
When misting module is in,fill with water on the outer ring part and water should flow through a small hole. Fill it just above the water sensor which is the little black bridge on the module itself.

Then set that aside and grab the lid.
Place a 40mm 24v fan on the hole preferably under the hole.
glue it in and take the lid and the wire, the wire will go thru a same hole as the misting module

strip the wires on a 24v ac adapter, the misting module and fan, connect the red to both red wires same with the black wire.
use electrical tape to close up the exposed wire.

Done! congrats you made a humidifier! plug it in and fight back dry air! no use
for me, I live in the insanely humid Florida!

description.text:
A big fat round PIG dog chew toy. Scanned 4 times with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner.   
The base, or feet, of this round pig aren't sufficient to print without a raft. I tried with just a raft and halfway through the print, it came loose. I recommend using at least a raft, and perhaps supports.

This is scanned from a squishy dog chew toy.  
The base, or feet, of this round pig aren't sufficient to print without a raft and supports. I tried with just a raft and halfway through the print, it came loose. I recommend using both a raft and supports.

I'm working on a 3D printable frame for a Balancing Robot.
Also i am going to add FPV to it, just because we can ! :D
This still is a work in progress.
Rims are done. ( 5mm dia. shaft with flattened side )
Put a piece of inner bike tube aroud the rims.
Working on the frame.
I have build the bot with what i had laying around, could use smaller steppers.
These are Nema 17 steppers. Which fit this frame perfect.

The hardware and firmware where designed by Joop Brokking.
You can see his youtube vid here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6WWqo-Yr8lA&google_comment_id=z13rvh5wokmixbwkh23ig3ooxtr5f5pg304

The only thing i want to change is the controller.
Joop made it with an Nintendo Wii controller, i 'd like to use a normal analog 2 axis joystick.
Also i want to make it controllable by an RC receiver.
I only changed the transmitter part of the code, not touching the firmware for the bot.
Also i'm going to write an PWM to BOT-Data Converter for the peolple who like to control the bot with their RC remotes. Code will be posted below the transmitter code when i have written it.
Here's the transmitter CoDe:

///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
// Balancing Bot Joystick Controller.
// Analog joystick connected to Pin A0 and A1
// Rewriten by Bitwise Operator - 29-5-2017
// Thanks to Joop Brokking for the original source
///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

define JoyA_PIN A0

define JoyB_PIN A1

int Joystick_A = 0;
int Joystick_B = 0;
int Joystick_A_Center = 520;
int Joystick_B_Center = 514;
int Joystick_A_DeadZone = 260;
int Joystick_B_DeadZone = 260;

void setup(){
pinMode(JoyA_PIN, INPUT);
pinMode(JoyB_PIN, INPUT);
Serial.begin(9600); //Start the serial port at 9600 kbps
delay(20); //Short delay
}

void readJoystick(){
Joystick_A = analogRead(JoyA_PIN); // Read analog Pins
Joystick_B = analogRead(JoyB_PIN); //
// Serial.println(Joystick_A); // this can be used to check center value
// Serial.println(Joystick_B); // do not use serial comms for anything else but the second last line of the propgram.
}

void loop(){
readJoystick();
send_byte = B00000000; //Set the send_byte variable to 0
if(Joystick_A < (Joystick_A_Center - (Joystick_A_DeadZone /2))) send_byte |= B00000001;
if(Joystick_A > (Joystick_A_Center + (Joystick_A_DeadZone /2))) send_byte |= B00000010;
if(Joystick_B < (Joystick_B_Center - (Joystick_B_DeadZone /2))) send_byte |= B00001000;
if(Joystick_B > (Joystick_B_Center + (Joystick_B_DeadZone /2))) send_byte |= B00000100;
if(send_byte) {
Serial.print((char)send_byte); //Send the send_byte variable if it's value is larger then 0
}
delay(40); //Create a 40 millisecond loop delay
}

title: Celtic Infinity Knot / Thor's Hammer (Mjölnir) Fidget Spinner

description.text:
This fidget spinner was created starting with a Celtic Infinity Knot design I had made a while ago. It is patterned after the version of the Celtic Infinity Knot that appears on Thor's Hammer (Mjölnir) in the Marvel Cinematic Universe movies.

The fidget spinner is designed to use a 608 Bearing as the center bearing and 3 1/2" ball bearings as weights.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm Layer Height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print one of each 3D model. I used PLA. If you use ABS you will probably want to use a brim as the main body will be prone to warping.

I kept the print speed down to increase dimensional accuracy and print quality.

Additional Equipment

608 Bearing
Quantity - 1
Diameter - 22mm
Height - 7mm
Inside Diameter - 8mm

1/2" Ball Bearings
Quantity - 3

Build Instructions
  1. Print all 3D printed parts.
  2. Insert all bearings. I find using something like mistertech's Spinner Press (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2275122) very helpful with this step.
  3. Insert the caps/grips. Be careful to ensure the two caps are aligned and press together from the centers as it takes a good deal of force and they are fragile until completely inserted. There will be a small gap between the caps and the bearing.
  4. Spin bahy-bee! Spin!

OpenSCAD

3D Model created using OpenSCAD version 2016.10.05.

description.text:
This is servo-based door lock controlled by Arduino Nano and powered by standard SG90 servo. The means to open the lock can be anything, from simple keypad trough magnetic hall sensors to Bluetooth or RFID.

This project contains complete material from Arduino Workshop SIG I did at ZodiaCon 2017.

In addition to STLs, there are the following files available:

  • Slides.pdf - presentation slides from my talk
  • Handbook-CS.pdf - lab handbook in Czech language
  • Handbook-EN.pdf - lab handbook in English language
  • Code.zip - source code for all labs

The following labs are included:

  1. Testing the environment (blinking the LED)
  2. Using the OH3144 Hall Sensor
  3. Using the 4x4 matrix keyboard
  4. Using the SG90 servo
  5. Simple lock controlled by magnetic sensor
  6. Simple lock controlled by keyboard
  7. Finished project - lock with changeable code stored in EEPROM.

The following electronic components are required:

  • Arduino Nano (or basically any Arduino, but the holder is designed for Nano)
  • OH3144 Hall Sensor
  • SG90 servo
  • 4x4 matrix keyboard

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

Some parts have 'light' variants (*_LT.stl). These are less robust, but print faster.
The rack and gear were inspired by Motorized Door Lock, but the other parts were created from scratch and designed for easy print.

Vintage styled key chain designed for small guest house with 5 rooms, include examples for numbers 1-5 and STL without any number on it for custom edit. Printed with 10% fill and had some issues with engraving, so recommend to go for 100%.

Printer:

Malyan M150

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

25 de abril bridge in 3D

We are the 7th E class from Agrupamento de Escolas Venda do Pinheiro, near Lisbon. We've made a project on anti-seismic structures in Portugal, focusing on bridges, specefically the 25 de Abril bridge, over the Tagus River. This project was created in several classes: ICT for learning 3D modeling; Portuguese Language for researching and information literacy and selection on the school library; Science class to learn about earth's internal structure, seismisc faults and seismic causes.

We've created a 3d model of the 25 de abril bridge, over the tagus river. We've used Sketchup Make for the model of the bridge and Maps to STL to generate the 3D map of the river span between Alcântara and Almada. The final project was assembled in Tinkercad and 3D printed on an beethefirst printer.

BEETHEFIRST
